subject: statistics
title: McNemar's Test
contentHtml: McNemar's test is a non-parametric statistical test used to compare the proportion of successes in two related samples.
intuition: McNemar's test is useful when you have paired data and want to determine if the proportion of successes in one sample differs significantly from another.
realWorldApplications: Comparing the performance of two classifiers on a validation set

subject: statistics
title: Paired t-test for Classifiers
contentHtml: The paired t-test is a statistical test used to compare the performance of two classifiers on the same dataset.
name: Paired t-test formula" },
problemHtml: Suppose we have two classifiers, A and B, that predict the same dataset. We want to test if there's a significant difference in their accuracy.

steps.description: Calculate the mean accuracy for each classifier
steps.explanation: We calculate the mean accuracy for each classifier by taking the average of their predictions.
We calculate the pooled standard deviation by combining the variances of each classifier's accuracy.
We calculate the t-statistic by dividing the difference in means by the pooled standard deviation and adjusting for sample sizes.

intuition: The paired t-test helps us determine if there's a statistically significant difference between two classifiers' performance on the same dataset.

subject: statistics
title: McNemar's Test for Paired Classifiers
contentHtml: When evaluating the performance of a classifier on paired data (e.g., before-and-after scenarios), McNemar's test provides a powerful tool to assess whether the changes are statistically significant.

workedExample.problemHtml: Suppose we have a classifier that predicts whether a customer will churn or not. We collect data on customers who received a promotional offer and those who did not. For each customer, we record their original class (churned or not) and the new class after receiving the offer.

steps.description: Count the number of customers who churned in both scenarios
steps.explanation: This represents the number of customers who would have churned regardless of the offer

steps.description: Count the number of customers who did not churn in both scenarios
steps.explanation: This represents the number of customers who would not have churned regardless of the offer

workedExample.finalAnswer: Compare the test statistic to the critical value or p-value to determine significance

intuition: McNemar's test helps us identify whether the changes in class are due to the classifier's performance or random chance
